25:T2861,<entryFree id="n2861" key="بَعُدَ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>1</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">بَعُدَ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">عد</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بعد</orth>
                  </form>, aor.      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Bu" lang="ar">بَعُدَ</orth>
                  </form>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">بُعْدٌ</foreign>; (S, L, Msb, K;) and <foreign lang="ar">بَعِدَ</foreign>, aor.      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Ba" lang="ar">بَعَدَ</orth>
                  </form>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">بَعَدٌ</foreign>; (L, K;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2861-1" target="ابعد" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n2863"/></foreign>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">إِبْعَادٌ</foreign>, which is also trans.; (Msb;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2861-2" target="تباعد" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n2864"/></foreign>; (S, Msb, K;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2861-3" target="استبعد" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>; (S, K, &amp;c.;) <hi rend="ital">He,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it, was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, distant, remote, far off,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">aloof: he went,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">removed,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">retired,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">withdrew himself, to a distance,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">far away,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">far off: he alienated,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">estranged, himself: he stood,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">kept, aloof: contr. of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">قَرُبَ</foreign>: (S, L:) [but <foreign lang="ar">بَعُدَ</foreign> generally has the first of these significations; and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2861-4" target="ابعد" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n2863"/></foreign>, the others, as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2861-5" target="تباعد" n="5" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n2864"/></foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2861-6" target="استبعد" n="6" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>:] it is the general opinion of the leading lexicologists that <foreign lang="ar">بَعِدَ</foreign>, as well as <foreign lang="ar">بَعُدَ</foreign>, is thus used; but some deny this; and some assert that they may be employed alike, but that <foreign lang="ar">بَعُدَ</foreign> is more chaste than <foreign lang="ar">بَعِدَ</foreign> thus used. (TA.) [You say also, of a desert, and a tract of country, and the like, <foreign lang="ar">بَعُدَ</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">It extended far.</hi>] And <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2861-7" target="ابعد" n="7" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar" select="n2863"/>زَيْدٌ عَنِ المَنْزِلِ</foreign>, meaning   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2861-8" target="تباعد" n="8" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n2864"/></foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">Zeyd went,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">removed, to a distance,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">far, from the place of alighting</hi> or <hi rend="ital">abode</hi>]. (IKt, Msb.) And <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2861-9" target="تباعد" n="9" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar" select="n2864"/>مِنِّى</foreign>, and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2861-10" target="ابتعد" n="10" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2861-11" target="تبعّد" n="11" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n2861"/></foreign>, [<hi rend="ital">He went,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">removed, to a distance,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">far, from me; he alienated,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">estranged, himself from me; he shunned,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">avoided, me;</hi>] (A;) and <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2861-12" target="تباعد" n="12" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar" select="n2864"/>عَنِّى</foreign> [and <foreign lang="ar">بَعُدَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عنّى</foreign> signify the same]. (Msb in art. <foreign lang="ar">كشح</foreign>.) And   
      <foreign lang="ar">إِذَا أَرَاذَ أَحَدُكُمْ الحَاجَةِ <ref cref="n2861-13" target="أَبْعَدَ" n="13" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, (L, Msb,) a trad., (Msb,) meaning <hi rend="ital">When one of you desires to accomplish that which is needful,</hi> (i. e. to ease nature,) <hi rend="ital">he goes far,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to a great distance.</hi> (L.) And <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2861-14" target="أَبْعَدْتُ" n="14" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>فِى المَذْهَبِ</foreign>, meaning   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2861-15" target="تَبَاعَدْتُ" n="15" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, (Msb,) <hi rend="ital">I went far,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to a great distance, to the place of ease,</hi> i. e., to ease nature. (L.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [<foreign lang="ar">بَعُدَ</foreign> referring to a saying or the like, and an event, means <hi rend="ital">It was far from being probable</hi> or <hi rend="ital">correct; it was improbable, extraordinary,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">strange:</hi> (see <foreign lang="ar">بَعِيدٌ</foreign>, and see also 10:) often occurring in these senses.] And <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2861-16" target="ابعد" n="16" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar" select="n2863"/>فِى نَوْعِهِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">It reached the utmost point,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">degree, in its kind,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">species.</hi> (IAth.) And <foreign lang="ar">ابعد فِى السَّوْمِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He exceeded the due bounds in offering a thing for sale and demanding a price for it,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in bargaining for a thing.</hi> (A.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">أَخَذَهُ مَا قَرُبَ وَ مَا بَعُدَ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Recent and old griefs took hold upon him:</hi> a saying similar to <foreign lang="ar">أَخَذَهُ مَا قَدُمَ وَ مَا حَدُثَ</foreign>. (Mgh in art. <foreign lang="ar">قدم</foreign>.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  [<foreign lang="ar">بَعُدَ</foreign> is often used, agreeably with a general rule, in the manner of a verb of praise or dispraise; and in this case is commonly contracted into <foreign lang="ar">بُعْدَ</foreign>, like <foreign lang="ar">حُسْنَ</foreign>; as in the phrase, in a verse of Imrael-Keys, <foreign lang="ar">بُعْدَ مَا مُتَأَمَّلى</foreign> (in which <foreign lang="ar">ما</foreign> is redundant) <hi rend="ital">Distant,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">far distant, was the object of my contemplation!</hi> or (as explained in the EM p. 52) <hi rend="ital">how distant,</hi> &amp;c.!]          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">بَعِدَ</foreign>, aor.      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Ba" lang="ar">بَعَدَ</orth>
                  </form>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">بَعَدٌ</foreign>; (S, L, Msb, K;) and <foreign lang="ar">بَعْدَ</foreign>, aor.      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Bu" lang="ar">بَعُدَ</orth>
                  </form>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">بُعْدٌ</foreign>; (L, K;) also signify <hi rend="ital">He,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it, perished:</hi> (S L, Msb:) <hi rend="ital">he died:</hi> (K:) it is the general opinion of the leading lexicologists that both these verbs are used as signifying “he perished,” and both occur in different readings of v. 98 of ch. xi. of the Kur: the former is said to be used in this sense by some of the Arabs; and the latter, by others; but some disallow the latter in this sense; and some say that the <hi rend="ital">former is more</hi> chaste than the latter thus used: (TA:) or both signify <hi rend="ital">he became far distant from his home</hi> or <hi rend="ital">native country; became a stranger,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">estranged, therefrom:</hi> (L, TA:) or the Arabs say, <foreign lang="ar">بَعِدَ الرَّجُلُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">بَعُدَ</foreign> in the sense of <foreign lang="ar">تباعد</foreign>, when not reviling; but when reviling, they say, <foreign lang="ar">بَعِدَ</foreign>, only. (Yoo, TA.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">لَا تَبْعَدٌ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">وَ إِنْ بَعُدْتَ عَنَّى</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Mayest thou not perish though thou be distant from me!</hi>] (A.) [And as an imprecation against a man, you say, <foreign lang="ar">بَعِدْتَ</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">Mayest thou perish!</hi> (See the printed edition of the Ham, pp. 89 and 90, where <foreign lang="ar">بَعِدْتَاىَ هلكت</foreign> is an evident mistake for <foreign lang="ar">َعِدْتَ أَى هَلَكْتَ</foreign>.)] And <foreign lang="ar">بُعْدًا لَهُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">May God alienate him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">estrange him, from good,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">prosperity!</hi> or, <hi rend="ital">curse him!</hi> (A, * K, TA;) i. e. may he not be pitied with respect to that which has befallen him! like <foreign lang="ar">سُحْقًا لَهُ</foreign>: the most approved way being to put <foreign lang="ar">بعد</foreign> thus in the accus. case as an inf. n.; but the tribe of Temeem say, <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2861-17" target="بُعْدٌ" n="17" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar" select="n2868"/>لَهُ</foreign>, and <foreign lang="ar">سُحْقٌ</foreign>, like <foreign lang="ar">غُلَامٌ لَهُ</foreign>. (TA.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">بَعُدَ</foreign> is made trans. by means of [the preposition] <foreign lang="ar">ب</foreign>: see 4. (Msb.)    </entryFree>26:Tdd3,<entryFree id="n2868" key="بُعْدٌ" type="main">

                  </form> [as an inf. n. used in the manner of a subst. signifies] <hi rend="ital">Distance,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">remoteness;</hi> (S, A, L, K; *) and so

(TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">أَبْعَدَهُ ٱللّٰهُ</foreign> means <hi rend="ital">May God alienate him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">estrange him, from good,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">prosperity!</hi> or, <hi rend="ital">curse him!</hi> (K;) i. e., may he not be pitied with respect to that which has befallen him! (A.)    </entryFree>28:T4ef,<entryFree id="n2864" key="تباعد" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>6</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">تباعد</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">باعد</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">تباعد</orth>
                  </form>: see 1, in six places.          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [It also signifies <hi rend="ital">He became alienated,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">estranged,</hi> from his family or friends.          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">تباعدوا</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">They became distant,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">remote, one from another; they went, removed, retired,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">withdrew themselves, to a distance, far away,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">far off, one from another; they removed themselves far,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">kept aloof, one from another.</hi>] You say, <foreign lang="ar">كَانُوا مُتَقَارِبِينَ فَتَبَاعَدُوا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">They were near, one to another, and they became distant,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">remote, one from another</hi>]. (A.)    </entryFree>29:T4f5,<entryFree id="n2865" key="استبعدهُ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>10</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">استبعدهُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">أستبعده</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">استبعده</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">استبعدة</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ٱستبعد</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ٱستبعده</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He reckoned it,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">esteemed it,</hi> (namely, a thing, K, or a saying, A,) <foreign lang="ar">بَعِيد</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">distant,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">remote;</hi> or if a saying or the like, <hi rend="ital">far from being probable</hi> or <hi rend="ital">correct, improbable, extraordinary,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">strange</hi>]; (S, A, K;) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2865-1" target="ابعدهُ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>. (A.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  See also 1, first sentence, in two places.    </entryFree>2a:T14bb,<entryFree id="n2866" key="بَعْدُ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">بَعْدُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">عد</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بعد</orth>
                  </form> an adv. n. of time, signifying <hi rend="ital">After,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">afterwards:</hi> and allowable also, accord. to some of the grammarians, as an adv. n. of place, signifying <hi rend="ital">after,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">behind:</hi> (TA:) <hi rend="ital">contr. of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">قَبْلُ</foreign>: (S, A, K:) it is a vague adv. n., of which the meaning is not understood without its being prefixed to another noun [expressed or implied]; denoting after-time. (Msb.) When it occurs without any complement, (S, K,) a noun or the like which should be its complement being intended to be understood as to the meaning thereof but not as to the letter, (S, * TA,) it is indecl., (S, K,) because it resembles a particle, (TA,) and has damm for its termination to show that it is indecl., since it cannot have damm by any rule of desinential syntax because it cannot occur as an agent nor as an inchoative or enunciative. (S.) Sb, however, mentions [as exceptions to this rule] the phrases <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ بَعْدٍ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Afterwards</hi>] and <foreign lang="ar">أَفْعَلُ هٰذَا بَعْدًا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">I will do this afterwards</hi>], as having been used by the Arabs. (K, * TA.) [The latter of these phrases is common in the present day. Another exception to the rule above-mentioned will be found in what follows.] Accord. to the primary rule, it is used as a prefixed n. governing its complement in the gen. case; (S;) [i. e., it is used in the manner of a preposition;] and when thus used, it is decl., (K,) because it does not in this case [always] resemble a particle. (TA.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">جَآءَ زَيْدٌ بَعْدَ عَمْرٍو</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Zeyd came after 'Amr.</hi> (Msb.) And <foreign lang="ar">رَأَيْتُهُ بَعْدَكَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بَعْدِكَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">I saw him after thee</hi>]. (L.) The words of the Kur [xxx. 3], <foreign lang="ar">ٱللّٰهِ ٱلْأَمْرُ مِنْ قَبْلُ وَ مِنْ بَعْدُ</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">To God</hi> belonged <hi rend="ital">the command before</hi> that the Greeks were overcome <hi rend="ital">and after</hi> that they had been overcome, [thus read when the complements of <foreign lang="ar">قبل</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">بعد</foreign> are intended to be understood as to the meaning thereof but not as to the letter,] are also read <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ قَبْلِ وَ مِنْ بَعْدِ</foreign>, when each complement is intended to be understood as to the meaning and the letter, and also <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ قَبْلٍ وَ مِنْ بَعْدٍ</foreign>, meaning To God belongeth the command <hi rend="ital">first and last,</hi> [when neither complement is intended to be understood either as to the letter or as to the meaning,] but the first of these readings is the best. (L.) [You say also, <foreign lang="ar">بَعْدَ ذٰلِكَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بَعْدِ ذٰلِكَ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">After that:</hi> and <foreign lang="ar">بَعْدَ أَنْ فَعَلْتُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بَعْدِ أَنْ فَعَلْتُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">بَعْدَ مَا فَعَلْتُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ بَعْدِ مَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">فَعَلْتُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">After I did,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">after my doing,</hi> such a thing: &amp;c.] Also <foreign lang="ar">جِئْتُ بَعْدَيْكُمَا</foreign>, meaning <foreign lang="ar">بَعْدَ كُمَا</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">I came after you two.</hi> (K.) And <foreign lang="ar">هٰذَا مِمَّا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">لَيْسَ بَعْدَهُ غَايَةٌ فِى الجَوْدَةِ</foreign>, and <foreign lang="ar">فِى الرَّدَآءَة</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">This is of the things after,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">beyond, which there is not any extreme degree in respect of goodness,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">in respect of badness:</hi> and, by way of abridgement, <foreign lang="ar">لَيْسَ بَعْدَهُ</foreign> [with nothing following this]: and hence, app., the saying of Mohammad, <foreign lang="ar">وَإِنْ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">كَانَ لَيْسَ بِالَّذِى لَا بَعْدَ لَهُ</foreign>, meaning [<hi rend="ital">And though</hi>] <hi rend="ital">it be not in the utmost degree</hi> in respect of goodness: <foreign lang="ar">بعد</foreign> being thus used as a decl. noun. (Mgh.)    </entryFree>2b:T194d,<entryFree id="n2867" key="بَعْدِى" type="main">[     
    <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">بَعْدِى</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">عد</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">عدي</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بعد</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بعدى</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بعدي</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بعديي</orth>
                  </form> and the like are also frequently used as meaning <foreign lang="ar">بَعْدَ عَهْدِى</foreign> and the like; as in the phrase, <foreign lang="ar">قَدْ تَغَيَّرْتَ بَعْدى</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Thou hast become altered since I knew thee,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">saw thee,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">met thee,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">was with thee.</hi> And similar to this are many phrases in the Kur; as, for instance, in ii. 48,] <foreign lang="ar">ثُمَّ ٱتَّخَذْتُمُ ٱلعِجْلَ مِنْ بَعْدِهِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Then ye took to yourselves the calf</hi> as a god, or an object of worship, <hi rend="ital">after him,</hi> namely Moses, i. e., <hi rend="ital">after his having gone away.</hi> (Bd.) <foreign lang="ar">أَمَّا بَعْدُ</foreign> (S, K, &amp;c.) is [an expression denoting transition;] an expression by which an address or a discourse is divided; (S;) used without any complement to <foreign lang="ar">بعد</foreign>, which in this case signifies the contr. of <foreign lang="ar">قَبْلُ</foreign>: (TA:) you say, <foreign lang="ar">أَمَّا بَعْدُ فَقَدْ كَانَ كَذَا</foreign>, meaning [<hi rend="ital">Now, after these preliminary words,</hi> (Abu-l- 'Abbás in TA voce <foreign lang="ar">خِطَابٌ</foreign>,) I proceed to say, that <hi rend="ital">such a thing has happened:</hi> or] <hi rend="ital">after my prayer for thee:</hi> (K:) or <hi rend="ital">after praising God:</hi> (TA:) the first who used this formula was David; (K;) or Jacob; (TA;) or Kaab Ibn-Lu-eí; (K;) or Kuss Ibn-Sá'ideh; or Yaarub Ibn-Kahtán. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  You also use the dim. form, saying   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2867-1" target="بُعَيْدَهُ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> [<hi rend="ital">A little after him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it</hi>], when you mean by it to denote a time near to the preceding time. (Msb.) You say also, <foreign lang="ar">رَأَيْتُهُ <ref cref="n2867-2" target="بُعَيْدَاتِ" n="2" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>بَيْنٍ</foreign>, (S, K,) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2867-3" target="بَعِيدَاتِهِ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, (K, TA, [in the CK <foreign lang="ar">بُعَيْدَاتِه</foreign>,]) <hi rend="ital">I saw him a little after a separation:</hi> (S, K:) or, <hi rend="ital">after intervals of separation:</hi> (S, L:) or, <hi rend="ital">after a while.</hi> (A'Obeyd, A.) And <foreign lang="ar">إِنَّهَا لَتَضْحَكُ  <ref cref="n2867-4" target="بُعَيْذَاتِ" n="4" type="6" subtype="FTFSO" lang="ar"/> بَيْنٍ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Verily she laughs after intervals.</hi> (L.) [See also art. <foreign lang="ar">بين</foreign>.]   
      <anchor/><foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2867-5" target="بُعَيْدَات" n="5" type="2" subtype="FPO" lang="ar"/></foreign> is used only as an adv. n. of time. (S, L.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">بَعْدُ</foreign> also sometimes means <hi rend="ital">Now; yet; as yet.</hi> (TA.) [It is used in this sense mostly in negative phrases; as, for instance, in <foreign lang="ar">لَمْ يَمُتْ بَعْدُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He has not died yet.</hi> The following is one of the instances of its having this meaning in affirmative phrases: <foreign lang="ar">سُمِّيَ الحَوْلِىُّ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ أَوْلَادِ البَقَرِ تَبِيعًا لِأَنَّهُ يَنْبَعُ أُمَّهُ بَعْدُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">The yearling of the offspring of cows is called</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">تبيع</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">because he yet follows his mother:</hi> occurring in the Mgh &amp;c., in art. <foreign lang="ar">تبع</foreign>.]          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  It occurs also in the sense of <foreign lang="ar">مَعَ</foreign>; as in the words of the Kur [ii. 174 and v. 95], <foreign lang="ar">فَمَنِ ٱعْتَدَى بَعْدَ ذٰلِكَ</foreign>, i. e., (as some say, MF,) <foreign lang="ar">مَعَ ذلك</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">And whoso transgresseth notwithstanding that;</hi> lit., <hi rend="ital">with that</hi>]. (Msb.)          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  It has been said that it also means <hi rend="ital">Before, in time;</hi> thus bearing two contr. significations: that it has this meaning in two instances; in the Kur [lxxix. 30], where it is said, <foreign lang="ar">وَ ٱلْأَرْضَ بَعْدَ ذٰلِكَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">دَحَاهَا</foreign> [as though signifying <hi rend="ital">And the earth, before that, He spread it forth</hi>]; and [xxi. 105] where it is said, <foreign lang="ar">وَلَقَدْ كَتَبْنَا فِى ٱلزَّبُورِ مِنْ بَعْدِ ٱلذِّكْرِ</foreign> [as though meaning <hi rend="ital">And verily we wrote in the Psalms before the Kur-án</hi>]: (MF, TA:) but Az says that this is a mistake; that God created the earth not spread forth; then created the heaven; and then spread forth the earth: (L, TA:) and <foreign lang="ar">الذكر</foreign> in the latter of these instances means <hi rend="ital">the Book of the Law revealed to Moses:</hi> (Bd:) or <foreign lang="ar">الزبور</foreign> means <hi rend="ital">the revealed Scriptures;</hi> (Bd, Jel;) and <foreign lang="ar">الذكر</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">the Preserved Tablet,</hi> (Bd,) [i. e.] <hi rend="ital">the Original of the Scriptures,</hi> which is with God. (Jel.)    </entryFree>2c:T1f20,<entryFree id="n2874" key="بَعِيدٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">بَعِيدٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">عيد</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بعيد</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Distant; remote; far; far off;</hi> (S, L, K; *) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2874-1" target="بُعَادٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n2872"/></foreign>, and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2874-2" target="بَاعِدٌ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>: (L, K:) pl. (of the first, S, L) <foreign lang="ar">بُعْدَانٌ</foreign> (S, L, K) and (of the first also, L, TA) <foreign lang="ar">بُعُدٌ</foreign> (L, K) and <foreign lang="ar">بِعَادٌ</foreign> (TA) and (of the first and second, L) <foreign lang="ar">بُعَدَآءُ</foreign> (L, K) and of the third,   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2874-3" target="بَعَدٌ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n2869"/></foreign>, [but this (which is also used as a sing. epithet, as will be shown in what follows,) is properly a quasi-pl. n.,] like as <foreign lang="ar">خَدَمٌ</foreign> is of <foreign lang="ar">خَادِمٌ</foreign>. (S.) As signifying <hi rend="ital">Distant with respect to place,</hi> it is correctly used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. and dual and pl.; (L, and TA in this art. and in art. <foreign lang="ar">قرب</foreign>, in which latter see the authorities;) but not necessarily; like its contr. <foreign lang="ar">قَرِيبٌ</foreign>: (L:) you say, <foreign lang="ar">هِىَ بَعِيدٌ مِنْكَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">She is distant from thee;</hi> or it is] as though you said, <foreign lang="ar">مَكَانُهَا بَعِيدٌ</foreign>: <pb n="226"/> (L:) also <foreign lang="ar">مَا أَنْتَ مِنَّا بِبَعِيدٍ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Thou art not distant from us </hi>], and <foreign lang="ar">مَا أَنْتُمْ مِنَّا بِبَعِيدٍ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Ye are not distant from us</hi>]: and in like manner, <foreign lang="ar">مِنَّا <ref cref="n2874-4" target="بِبَعَدٍ" n="4" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>مَا أَنْتَ</foreign>, and   
      <foreign lang="ar">مَا أَنْتُمُ مِنَّا <ref cref="n2874-5" target="بِبَعَدٍ" n="5" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>. (S, TA.) [But it receives, sometimes, the fem. form when used in this sense; for] <foreign lang="ar">جَلَسْتُ بَعِيدًا مِنْكَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">بَعِيدَةٌ مِنْكَ</foreign> are phrases mentioned as signifying <hi rend="ital">I sat distant,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">remote in place,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">at a distance,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">aloof, from thee;</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مَكَانًا</foreign> [and <foreign lang="ar">نَاحِيَةً</foreign> or the like] being understood. (L.) You say also,   
      <foreign lang="ar">مَنْزِلٌ <ref cref="n2874-6" target="بَعَدٌ" n="6" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n2869"/></foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">A distant,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">remote, place of alighting</hi> or <hi rend="ital">abode.</hi> (K.) And <foreign lang="ar">تَنَحَّ غَيْرَ بَعِيدٍ</foreign> (S, K) and   
      <foreign lang="ar">غَيْرَ <ref cref="n2874-7" target="بَاعِدٍ" n="7" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar">غَيْرَ <ref cref="n2874-8" target="بَعَدٍ" n="8" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> (K) [<hi rend="ital">Retire thou not far;</hi>] meaning <hi rend="ital">be thou near:</hi> (S, K:) [or] the second and third of these phrases mean <hi rend="ital">retire thou not in an abject,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a mean,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">contemptible,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">despicable, state.</hi> (S, A.) And   
      <foreign lang="ar">اِنْطَلِقْ يَا فُلَانُ غَيْرَ <ref cref="n2874-9" target="بَاعِدٍ" n="9" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Depart thou, O such a one, not far;</hi>] meaning <hi rend="ital">mayest thou not go away!</hi> (L.) [And <foreign lang="ar">رَأَيْتُهُ مِنْ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بَعِيدٍ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">I saw him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it, from afar:</hi> and <foreign lang="ar">جَآءَ مِنْ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بَعِيدٍ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He came from afar:</hi> and the like. And <foreign lang="ar">بَعِيدٌ</foreign> as applied to a desert and the like, meaning <hi rend="ital">Far extending.</hi>] And   
      <foreign lang="ar">بُعْدٌ <ref cref="n2874-10" target="بَاعِدٌ" n="10" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">A far distance.</hi> (K.) [And <foreign lang="ar">نِيَّةٌ بَعِيدَةٌ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">A distant, far-reaching,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">far-aiming, intention, purpose,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">design.</hi>] And <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٌ بَعِيدُ الهِمَّةِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Such a one is far-aiming,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">faraspiring, in purpose, desire,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ambition</hi>]. (A.) And <foreign lang="ar">هِىَ بَعِيدَةُ العَهْدِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">She was known,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">seen,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">met, a long time ago</hi>]: in this case, the fem. form, with <foreign lang="ar">ة</foreign>, must be used. (L.) And <foreign lang="ar">قَوْلٌ بَعِيدٌ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">A saying far from being probable</hi> or <hi rend="ital">correct; improbable; far-fetched; extraordinary,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">strange</hi>]. (A.) And <foreign lang="ar">أَمْرٌ بَعِيدٌ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">An extraordinary thing</hi> or <hi rend="ital">affair</hi> or <hi rend="ital">case, of which the like does not happen</hi> or <hi rend="ital">occur.</hi> (L.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  Also <hi rend="ital">Distant with respect to kindred</hi> or <hi rend="ital">relationship:</hi> in which sense, the word receives the fem. form, [as well as the dual form, and pl. forms, like its contr. <foreign lang="ar">قَرِيبٌ</foreign>,] by universal consent. (TA.) [Its pl.] <foreign lang="ar">بُعَدَآءُ</foreign> signifies <hi rend="ital">Strangers, that are not relations.</hi> (IAth.) You say also, <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٌ مِنْ بُعْدَانِ الأَمِيرِ</foreign> [meaning <hi rend="ital">Such a one is of the distant dependents,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">subjects, of the governor,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">prince</hi>]. (S.) And <foreign lang="ar">إِذَا لَمْ تَكُنْ مِنْ قُرْبَانِ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">الأَمِيرِ فَكُنْ مِنْ بُعْدَانِهِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">If thou be not of the particular companions,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">familiars, of the governor,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">prince, then be of his distant dependents,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">subjects</hi>]; i. e., be distant from him, that his evil may not affect thee. (AZ, A.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">رَأَيْتُهُ بَعِيدَاتِ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنٍ</foreign>: see <foreign lang="ar">بَعْدٌ</foreign> in the latter half of the paragraph.          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  See also <foreign lang="ar">بَاعِدٌ</foreign>.    </entryFree>2d:T14a3,<entryFree id="n2877" key="أَبْعَدُ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">أَبْعَدُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">More,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">most, distant</hi> or <hi rend="ital">remote; further,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">furthest:</hi> by poetic licence written <foreign lang="ar">أَبْعَدُّ</foreign>: (L:) [pl. <foreign lang="ar">أَبَاعِدُ</foreign>; as in the saying,] <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٌ يَسْتَجِرُّ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">الحَدِيثَ مِنْ أَبَاعِدِ أَطْرَافِهِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Such a one draws forth talk,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">discourse,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">news,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the like, from its most remote sources</hi>]. (A.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">More,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">most, extreme, excessive, egregious,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">extraordinary,</hi> in its kind. (IAth.) [Hence, perhaps,] <foreign lang="ar">إِنَّهُ لَغَيْرُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَبْعَدَ</foreign> [in the CK <foreign lang="ar">أَبْعَدٍ</foreign>] and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2877-1" target="بُعَدٍ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Verily there is no good in him:</hi> (K:) or, <hi rend="ital">no depth in him in anything:</hi> (IAar:) [or, <hi rend="ital">he is not extraordinary</hi> in his kind: see also <foreign lang="ar">بُعْدٌ</foreign>:] said in dispraising one. (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">مَا عِنْدَهُ أَبْعَدُ</foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n2877-2" target="بُعَدٌ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> [<hi rend="ital">He has not what is extraordinary</hi> in its kind: or] <hi rend="ital">he possesses not excellence,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">power,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">riches:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">he possesses not anything profitable:</hi> (L, K:) said only in dispraising one: (AZ:) or it may mean <hi rend="ital">he possesses not anything which one would go far to seek;</hi> or, <hi rend="ital">anything of value:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">what he possesses, of things or qualities that are desirable, is more extraordinary than what others possess.</hi> (MF.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">Remote from good:</hi> [which is the meaning generally intended in the present day when it is used absolutely as an epithet applied to a man; but meaning also <hi rend="ital">remote</hi> from him or those in whose presence this epithet is used, both <hi rend="ital">as to place and as to moral condition:</hi>] and, <hi rend="ital">from continence:</hi> (L:) and <hi rend="ital">stupid; foolish;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">having little,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">no, intellect</hi> or <hi rend="ital">understanding;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">حَائِنٌ</foreign>: (so in a copy of the S and in the L and TA:) or <hi rend="ital">treacherous,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">unfaithful;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">خَائِنٌ</foreign> (So in two copies of the S and in a copy of the A.) It is used as an allusion to the name of a person whom one would mention with dispraise; as when one says, <foreign lang="ar">هَلَكَ الأَبْعَدُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">May such a one, the remote from good,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">perish!</hi>]: with respect to a woman, one says, <foreign lang="ar">هَلَكَتِ البُعْدَى</foreign>. (En-Nadr, Az.) One says also, <foreign lang="ar">كَبَّ ٱللّٰهُ الأَبْعَدَ لِفِيهِ</foreign>, meaning [<hi rend="ital">May God cast down prostrate such a one, the remote from good,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">upon his mouth!</hi> or,] <hi rend="ital">cast him down upon his face!</hi> (S.) [It is a rule observed in decent society, by the Arabs, to avoid, as much as possible, the mention of opprobrious epithets, lest any person present should imagine an epithet of this kind to be slily applied to himself: therefore, when any malediction or vituperation is uttered, it is usual to allude to the object by the term <foreign lang="ar">الأَبْعَد</foreign>, or <foreign lang="ar">البَعِيد</foreign>, as meaning the remote from good, &amp;c., and also the remote from the person or persons present. See also <foreign lang="ar">الأَخِرُ</foreign>, which is used in a similar manner.]          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">A more distant,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">most distant,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">very distant, relation;</hi> (Lth;) <hi rend="ital">contr. of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَقْرَبُ</foreign>: (Msb:) pl. <foreign lang="ar">أَبَاعِدُ</foreign> (Lth, S, A, Msb, K) and <foreign lang="ar">أَبْعَدُونَ</foreign>; (Lth;) <hi rend="ital">contr. of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَقَارِبُ</foreign> (Lth, S, K) and <foreign lang="ar">أَقْرَبُونَ</foreign>. (Lth.)    </entryFree>11:["$","$Lc",null,{"direction":"row","alignItems":"flex-start","width":"100%","background":"white","padding":{"base":"16px 8px","md":"24px 24px 32px
